# Norse activity in the British Isles

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

See also: [Viking expansion § British
Isles](/wiki/Viking_expansion#British_Isles "Viking expansion"), [Viking Age §
Northwestern Europe](/wiki/Viking_Age#Northwestern_Europe "Viking Age"), and
[Invasions of the British Isles § Viking raids and
invasions](/wiki/Invasions_of_the_British_Isles#Viking_raids_and_invasions
"Invasions of the British Isles")

![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png) |  The examples and perspective in this article **may not[include all significant viewpoints](/wiki/Wikipedia:WikiProject_Countering_systemic_bias "Wikipedia:WikiProject Countering systemic bias")**. Please [improve the article](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Norse_activity_in_the_British_Isles&action=edit) or [discuss the issue](/wiki/Talk:Norse_activity_in_the_British_Isles "Talk:Norse activity in the British Isles"). _(October 2011)_ _([Learn how and when to remove this template message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))_  
---|---  
  
**Norse activity in the British Isles** occurred during the [Early Medieval
period](/wiki/Early_Medieval "Early Medieval") when members of the
[Norse](/wiki/Norsemen "Norsemen") populations of
[Scandinavia](/wiki/History_of_Scandinavia "History of Scandinavia") travelled
to [Britain](/wiki/Great_Britain "Great Britain") and [Ireland](/wiki/Ireland
"Ireland") to settle, trade or raid. The [Norse peoples](/wiki/Norse_peoples
"Norse peoples") who came to the [British Isles](/wiki/British_Isles "British
Isles") have been generally referred to as [Vikings](/wiki/Vikings
"Vikings"),[1][2] but it is a matter of debate if the term _Viking_
represented all Norse settlers or just those who raided.[3]

At the start of the Early Medieval period, Norse kingdoms of Scandinavia had
developed trade links across southern Europe and the Mediterranean, giving
them access to foreign imports such as silver, gold, bronze and spices. These
trade links also extended westward into Ireland and the British Isles.[4]

In the last decade of the 8th century AD, Norse raiders sacked a series of
Christian monasteries located in what is now the [United
Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom"), beginning in 793, with a raid
on the coastal monastery of [Lindisfarne](/wiki/Lindisfarne "Lindisfarne") on
the east coast of [England](/wiki/England_in_the_Middle_Ages "England in the
Middle Ages"). The following year they sacked the nearby [Monkwearmouth-Jarrow
Abbey](/wiki/Monkwearmouth-Jarrow_Abbey "Monkwearmouth-Jarrow Abbey"), and in
795 they attacked again, raiding [Iona Abbey](/wiki/Iona_Abbey "Iona Abbey")
on [Scotland](/wiki/Scotland_in_the_Early_Middle_Ages "Scotland in the Early
Middle Ages")'s west coast.[5]

##
Background[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Norse_activity_in_the_British_Isles&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Background")]

During the Early Medieval period, Ireland and Britain were culturally,
linguistically and religiously divided into various peoples. The languages of
the [Celtic Britons](/wiki/Celtic_Britons "Celtic Britons") and
[Gaels](/wiki/Gaels "Gaels") were descended from the [Celtic
languages](/wiki/Celtic_languages "Celtic languages") spoken by those of [Iron
Age](/wiki/Iron_Age "Iron Age") Europe. In [Ireland](/wiki/Ireland "Ireland"),
parts of western [Scotland](/wiki/Scotland "Scotland"), as well as the [Isle
of Man](/wiki/Isle_of_Man "Isle of Man"), people were speaking an early form
of [Gaelic](/wiki/Goidelic_languages "Goidelic languages") known as [Old
Irish](/wiki/Old_Irish "Old Irish"). There may have been another [pre-Indo-
European](/wiki/Goidelic_substrate_hypothesis "Goidelic substrate hypothesis")
language spoken by the [Erainn](/wiki/Iverni "Iverni") up until the 8th
century in what is today [Kerry](/wiki/County_Kerry "County Kerry"), but this
is likely to have been Celtic or some other Indo-European language. In Western
Britain, which includes; [Cornwall](/wiki/Cornwall "Cornwall"),
[Cumbria](/wiki/Cumbria "Cumbria"), [Wales](/wiki/Wales "Wales"), and
Southwest Scotland, the Celtic [Brythonic languages](/wiki/Brythonic_languages
"Brythonic languages") were spoken, with modern descendants such as
[Welsh](/wiki/Welsh_language "Welsh language") and
[Cornish](/wiki/Cornish_language "Cornish language") still being used. In
Northern Britain, past the Forth and Clyde rivers which constitutes a large
portion of modern-day Scotland, dwelled the Picts who spoke the
[Pictish](/wiki/Pictish_Language "Pictish Language") language. Due to the
scarcity of writing in Pictish, all of which can be found in
[Ogham](/wiki/Ogham "Ogham"), views are conflicted as to whether Pictish was
Celtic like the southernly languages, or perhaps even a non-Indo-European
language like [Basque](/wiki/Basque_Language "Basque Language"). However, most
inscriptions and place names hint towards the Picts being Celtic in language
and culture. Most peoples of Britain and Ireland had already predominantly
converted to [Christianity](/wiki/Christianity "Christianity") from their
older, pre-Christian [polytheistic](/wiki/Polytheism "Polytheism") religions.
In contrast to the rest of the isles though, much of southern Britain was
considered to be part of [Anglo-Saxon England](/wiki/Anglo-Saxon_England
"Anglo-Saxon England"), where [Anglo-Saxon](/wiki/Anglo-Saxons "Anglo-Saxons")
migrants from continental Europe had settled during the 5th century CE,
bringing with them their own [Germanic language](/wiki/Germanic_languages
"Germanic languages") (known as [Old English](/wiki/Old_English "Old
English")), a polytheistic religion ([Anglo-Saxon paganism](/wiki/Anglo-
Saxon_paganism "Anglo-Saxon paganism")) and their own distinct cultural
practices. By the time of the Viking incursions though, Anglo-Saxon England
had too become mostly Christian.

The Isle of Man had supported its own agrarian population, but it is widely
believed that it was Brythonic-speaking before Old Irish (later to become
[Manx](/wiki/Manx_language "Manx language")) spread there.
[Gaelicisation](/wiki/Gaelicisation "Gaelicisation") could have taken place
before the Viking age or perhaps during it, when the area was settled by
Norse-Gaels who practised their own culture.

In northern Britain, in the area roughly corresponding to modern-day Scotland,
lived three distinct ethnic groups in their own respective kingdoms; the
[Picts](/wiki/Picts "Picts"), [Scots](/wiki/Scottish_people "Scottish people")
and [Britons](/wiki/Britons_\(historical\) "Britons \(historical\)").[6] The
Pictish cultural group dominated the majority of Scotland, with major
populations concentrated between the [Firth of Forth](/wiki/Firth_of_Forth
"Firth of Forth") and the [River Dee](/wiki/River_Dee,_Aberdeenshire "River
Dee, Aberdeenshire"), as well as in [Sutherland](/wiki/Sutherland
"Sutherland"), [Caithness](/wiki/Caithness "Caithness"), and
[Orkney](/wiki/Orkney "Orkney").[7] The Scots were, according to written
sources, a tribal group which had crossed to Britain from
[Dalriada](/wiki/Dalriada "Dalriada") in the north of Ireland during the late
5th century. Archaeologists have not been able to identify anything that was
unique to the kingdom of the Scots, noting similarities with the Picts in most
forms of material culture.[8] The Britons were those dwelling in the [Old
North](/wiki/Hen_Ogledd "Hen Ogledd"), in parts of what have become southern
Scotland and northern England, and by the 7th or 8th centuries, had apparently
come under the political control of the Anglo-Saxons.[9]

By the mid-9th century, Anglo-Saxon England was divided into four separate and
independent kingdoms; [East Anglia](/wiki/Kingdom_of_East_Anglia "Kingdom of
East Anglia"), [Wessex](/wiki/Wessex "Wessex"),
[Northumbria](/wiki/Northumbria "Northumbria"), and [Mercia](/wiki/Mercia
"Mercia"), the latter of which was the strongest military power.[10] Between
half a million and a million people lived in England at this time, with
society being rigidly hierarchical. This class system had a king and his
[ealdormen](/wiki/Ealdormen "Ealdormen") at the top, under whom were the
[thegns](/wiki/Thegns "Thegns"), or landholders, and then the various forms of
agricultural workers below them. Beneath all of these was a class of slaves,
who may have made up as much as a quarter of the population.[10] The majority
of the populace lived in the countryside, although a few large towns had
developed, namely [London](/wiki/London "London") and [York](/wiki/York
"York"), which were centres of royal and ecclesiastical administration. There
was also a number of trading ports, such as [Hamwic](/wiki/Hamwic "Hamwic")
and [Ipswich](/wiki/Ipswich "Ipswich"), where foreign trade took place .[10]

###
Scandinavia[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Norse_activity_in_the_British_Isles&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Scandinavia")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Reconstructed_Viking_longboat_%22Hugin%22.jpg/220px-
Reconstructed_Viking_longboat_%22Hugin%22.jpg)](/wiki/File:Reconstructed_Viking_longboat_%22Hugin%22.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Reconstructed_Viking_longboat_%22Hugin%22.jpg "Enlarge")

A 20th century replica of a Viking longship, known as the
_[Hugin](/wiki/Hugin_\(longship\) "Hugin \(longship\)")_

Society in 8th century Scandinavia was, unlike parts of the British Isles,
still pre-literate, existing in the final stages of European
[prehistory](/wiki/Prehistory "Prehistory"), known to archaeologists as the
[Iron Age](/wiki/Iron_Age_Scandinavia "Iron Age Scandinavia"). In Scandinavia,
the 8th century proved to be "a period of rapid technological, economic and
social development" which would lead the region out of the Iron Age and into
what has come to be known as the [Viking Age](/wiki/Viking_Age "Viking
Age").[11]

At the start of the Early Mediaeval period, the Norse populations saw
themselves primarily as inhabitants of specific locations, such as
[Jutland](/wiki/Jutland "Jutland"), [Vestfold](/wiki/Vestfold "Vestfold") and
[Hordaland](/wiki/Hordaland "Hordaland"). It would only be in the later
centuries that the national identities would develop amongst the
Scandinavians, dividing them into such national groups as the
[Danes](/wiki/Danes "Danes"), [Swedes](/wiki/Swedes "Swedes") and
[Norwegians](/wiki/Norwegians "Norwegians").[12]

The Late Iron Age peoples of Scandinavia had not yet been converted to
Christianity as the peoples of Britain and Ireland had, and instead followed
[Norse paganism](/wiki/Norse_paganism "Norse paganism"), a polytheistic set of
beliefs that revered such deities as [Odin](/wiki/Odin "Odin"),
[Thor](/wiki/Thor "Thor"), [Frey](/wiki/Frey "Frey") and [Freyja](/wiki/Freyja
"Freyja").[13]

Scandinavian society was heavily dependent on fishing herring, and when that
failed, the seafaring Norse sailors turned to navigating around much of Europe
during the Early Mediaeval period.[14] The Norse populations of Scandinavia
had developed trade links with many areas of Europe, obtaining large
quantities of gold in the late 5th century, most of which had been found in
Sweden, and to a lesser extent, Norway.[4]

## Viking raids: 793–850
AD[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Norse_activity_in_the_British_Isles&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Viking raids: 793–850 AD")]

In the final decade of the 8th century AD, Norse raiders attacked a series of
Christian monasteries located in the British Isles. In the British Isles,
Christian monasteries had often been positioned on small islands and in other
remote coastal areas so that the monks could dwell there in seclusion,
devoting themselves to worship without the interference of other elements of
society. At the same time, it made them isolated and unprotected targets for
attack.[15] Historian [Peter Hunter Blair](/wiki/Peter_Hunter_Blair "Peter
Hunter Blair") remarked that the Viking raiders would have been astonished "at
finding so many communities which housed considerable wealth and whose
inhabitants carried no arms."[15] These raids would have been the first
contact many Norsemen had with Christianity, but such attacks were not
specifically anti-Christian in nature, rather the monasteries were simply seen
as 'easy targets' for raiders.[13]

Lo, it is nearly 350 years that we and our fathers have inhabited this most
lovely land, and never before has such a terror appeared as we have now
suffered from a pagan race, nor was it thought that such an inroad from the
sea could be made. Behold the church of St Cuthbert spattered with the blood
of the priests of God, despoiled of all its ornaments.

Archbishop [Alcuin of York](/wiki/Alcuin_of_York "Alcuin of York") on the
sacking of Lindisfarne.[16]

The first known account of a Viking raid taking place in Anglo-Saxon England
comes from 789, when three ships from [Hordaland](/wiki/Hordaland "Hordaland")
(in modern Norway) landed in the [Isle of Portland](/wiki/Isle_of_Portland
"Isle of Portland") on the southern coast of Wessex. They were approached by
the royal reeve from [Dorchester](/wiki/Dorchester,_Dorset "Dorchester,
Dorset"), whose job it was to identify all foreign merchants entering the
kingdom, and they proceeded to kill him.[16] It is likely that other raids
(the records for which have since been lost) occurred soon after, for in 792
King [Offa of Mercia](/wiki/Offa_of_Mercia "Offa of Mercia") began to make
arrangements for the defence of Kent from raids perpetrated by "pagan
peoples".[16]

The next recorded attack against the Anglo-Saxons came the following year, in
793, when the monastery at [Lindisfarne](/wiki/Lindisfarne "Lindisfarne"), an
island off England's eastern coast, was sacked by a Viking raiding party on 8
June.[16] The following year they sacked the nearby [Monkwearmouth-Jarrow
Abbey](/wiki/Monkwearmouth-Jarrow_Abbey "Monkwearmouth-Jarrow Abbey").[5]

In 795 they once again attacked, this time raiding [Iona
Abbey](/wiki/Iona_Abbey "Iona Abbey") on Scotland's west coast.[5] This
monastery would be attacked again in 802 and 806, when 68 people dwelling
there were killed. Following such devastation, the monastic community at Iona
abandoned the site and fled instead to [Kells](/wiki/Kells,_County_Meath
"Kells, County Meath") in Ireland.[17]

In the first decade of the 9th century AD, Viking raiders began to attack
coastal districts along Ireland.[18] In 835, the first major Viking raid in
southern England took place and was directed against the [Isle of
Sheppey](/wiki/Isle_of_Sheppey "Isle of Sheppey").[19]

### Treasure
hoards[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Norse_activity_in_the_British_Isles&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Treasure hoards")]

Various [hoards](/wiki/Hoards "Hoards") of treasure were buried in England at
this time, some of which may have been deposited by Anglo-Saxons attempting to
hide their wealth from Viking raiders, and some of which may have instead been
buried by the Viking raiders themselves as a way of protecting their looted
treasure.[16]

One of these hoards, discovered in [Croydon](/wiki/Croydon "Croydon")
(historically part of [Surrey](/wiki/Surrey "Surrey"), now part of [Greater
London](/wiki/Greater_London "Greater London")) in 1862, contained 250 coins,
three silver ingots and part of a fourth as well as four pieces of hack silver
in a linen bag. Archaeologists interpret this as loot collected by a member of
the Viking army. By dating the artefacts, archaeologists came to believe that
it was likely that this hoard had been buried in 872, when the army wintered
in London.[16] The coins themselves came from a wide range of different
kingdoms, with Wessex, Mercian and East Anglian examples found alongside
foreign imports from [Carolingian-dynasty](/wiki/Carolingian_dynasty
"Carolingian dynasty") [Francia](/wiki/Francia "Francia") and from the Arab
world.[16] Not all such Viking hoards in England contain coins, however – for
example, at [Bowes Moor](/wiki/Bowes_Moor "Bowes Moor"),
[Durham](/wiki/Durham,_England "Durham, England"), 19 silver ingots were
discovered, whilst at Orton Scar, [Cumbria](/wiki/Cumbria "Cumbria"), a silver
neck-ring and penannular brooch were uncovered.[20]

The historian Peter Hunter Blair believed that the success of the Viking raids
and the "complete unpreparedness of Britain to meet such attacks" became major
factors in the subsequent Norse invasions and colonisation of large parts of
the British Isles.[15]

## Invasion and Danelaw:
865–896[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Norse_activity_in_the_British_Isles&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Invasion and Danelaw: 865–896")]

From 865 the Norse attitude towards the British Isles changed, as they began
to see it as a place for potential colonisation rather than simply a place to
raid. As a result of this, larger armies began arriving on Britain's shores,
with the intention of conquering land and constructing settlements there.[21]

###

In 866, Norse armies captured York, one of the two major cities in Anglo-Saxon
England.[21] In 871, King [Æthelred of Wessex](/wiki/%C3%86thelred_of_Wessex
"Æthelred of Wessex"), who had been leading the conflict against the Vikings,
died and was succeeded to the throne by his younger brother, [Alfred the
Great](/wiki/Alfred_the_Great "Alfred the Great").[21] Meanwhile, many Anglo-
Saxon kings began to capitulate to the Viking demands, and handed over land to
the invading Norse settlers. In 876, the Northumbrian monarch
[Healfdene](/wiki/Healfdene "Healfdene") gave up his lands to them, and in the
next four years they gained further land in the kingdoms of Mercia and East
Anglia as well.[21] King Alfred continued his conflict with the invading
forces, but was driven back into [Somerset](/wiki/Somerset "Somerset") in the
south-west of his kingdom in 878, where he was forced to take refuge in the
marshes of [Athelney](/wiki/Athelney "Athelney").[21]

Alfred regrouped his military forces and defeated the armies of the Norse
monarch of East Anglia, [Guthrum](/wiki/Guthrum "Guthrum"), at the [Battle of
Edington](/wiki/Battle_of_Edington "Battle of Edington"). Following Guthrum's
defeat, in 886 the [Treaty of Wedmore](/wiki/Treaty_of_Wedmore "Treaty of
Wedmore") was signed between the (Norse-controlled) East Anglian and Wessex
governments that established a boundary between the two kingdoms. The area to
the north and east of this boundary became known as the
[Danelaw](/wiki/Danelaw "Danelaw") because it was under the control of Norse
political influence, whilst those areas south and west of it remained under
Anglo-Saxon dominance.[21] Alfred's government set about constructing a series
of defended towns or _burhs_ , began the construction of a navy and organised
a militia system whereby half of his peasant army remained on active
service.[21] Although there were continuous attacks on Wessex by new Viking
armies, the kingdom's new defences proved a success and in 896 the invaders
dispersed, instead settling in East Anglia and Northumbria, with some instead
sailing to [Normandy](/wiki/Normandy "Normandy").[21]

Alfred's policy of opposing the Viking settlers was continued under the regime
of his daughter [Æthelflæd](/wiki/%C3%86thelfl%C3%A6d "Æthelflæd"), who
married [Æthelred, Ealdorman of
Mercia](/wiki/%C3%86thelred,_Ealdorman_of_Mercia "Æthelred, Ealdorman of
Mercia"), and also under the regime of her brother [Edward the
Elder](/wiki/Edward_the_Elder "Edward the Elder"). In 920 the Northumbrian
government and the Scots governments both submitted to the military power of
Wessex, and in 937 the [Battle of Brunanburh](/wiki/Battle_of_Brunanburh
"Battle of Brunanburh") led to the collapse of Norse power in northern
Britain. In 954 [Erik Bloodaxe](/wiki/Erik_Bloodaxe "Erik Bloodaxe"), the last
Norse King of York, was expelled from the city.[22]

### Norse settlement in the British
Isles[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Norse_activity_in_the_British_Isles&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Norse settlement in the British Isles")]

The early Norse settlers in Anglo-Saxon England would have appeared visibly
different from the Anglo-Saxon populace, wearing specifically Scandinavian
styles of jewellery, and probably also wearing their own peculiar styles of
clothing as well. There was also a difference in the style of hair worn by
Norse and Anglo-Saxon men, with the former typically wearing a hair style that
was shaved at the back and left shaggy on the front, whilst in contrast to
this the latter typically wore their hair long.[23]

## Second invasion:
980–1012[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Norse_activity_in_the_British_Isles&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Second invasion: 980–1012")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Knutrike.png/220px-
Knutrike.png)](/wiki/File:Knutrike.png)

[](/wiki/File:Knutrike.png "Enlarge")

[Cnut the Great](/wiki/Cnut_the_Great "Cnut the Great")'s domains, in red

###
England[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Norse_activity_in_the_British_Isles&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: England")]

Under the reign of Wessex King [Edgar the Peaceful](/wiki/Edgar_the_Peaceful
"Edgar the Peaceful"), England came to be further politically unified, with
Edgar coming to be recognized as the king of all England by both Anglo-Saxon
and Norse populations living in the country.[24] However, under the regimes of
his son [Edward the Martyr](/wiki/Edward_the_Martyr "Edward the Martyr"), who
was murdered in 978, and then [Æthelred the
Unready](/wiki/%C3%86thelred_the_Unready "Æthelred the Unready"), the
political strength of the English monarchy waned, and in 980 Viking raiders
from Scandinavia once more started making attacks against England.[24] The
English government decided that the only way of dealing with these attackers
was to pay them [protection money](/wiki/Protection_money "Protection money"),
and so in 991 they gave them £10,000. This fee did not prove to be enough, and
over the next decade the English kingdom was forced to pay the Viking
attackers increasingly large sums of money.[24] Many English began to demand
that a more hostile approach be taken against the Vikings, and so, on [St
Brice's Day](/w/index.php?title=St_Brice%27s_Day&action=edit&redlink=1 "St
Brice's Day \(page does not exist\)") in 1002, King Æthelred proclaimed that
all Danes living in England would be executed. It would come to be known as
the [St. Brice's Day massacre](/wiki/St._Brice%27s_Day_massacre "St. Brice's
Day massacre").[24]

The news of the massacre reached King [Sweyn Forkbeard](/wiki/Sweyn_Forkbeard
"Sweyn Forkbeard") in Denmark. It is believed that Sweyn's sister
[Gunhilde](/wiki/Gunhilde "Gunhilde") could have been among the victims, which
prompted Sweyn to raid England the following year where Exeter was burned
down. Hampshire, Wiltshire, Wilton and Salisbury also became victims to the
viking revenge attack. Sweyn continued his raid in England and in 1004 his
viking army looted East Anglia, plundered Thetford and sacked Norwich, before
he once again returned to Denmark.

Further raids took place in 1006–1007, and in 1009–1012 [Thorkell the
Tall](/wiki/Thorkell_the_Tall "Thorkell the Tall") led a Viking invasion into
England.

In 1013 [Sweyn Forkbeard](/wiki/Sweyn_Forkbeard "Sweyn Forkbeard") returned to
invade England with a large army, and Æthelred fled to Normandy, leading Sweyn
to take the English throne. Sweyn died within a year however, and so Æthelred
returned, but in 1016 another Norse army invaded, this time under the control
of the Danish King [Cnut](/wiki/Cnut "Cnut") son of [Sweyn
Forkbeard](/wiki/Sweyn_Forkbeard "Sweyn Forkbeard").[25] After defeating
Anglo–Saxon forces at the [Battle of Assandun](/wiki/Battle_of_Assandun
"Battle of Assandun"), Cnut became king of England, subsequently ruling over
both the Danish and English kingdoms.[25] Following Cnut's death in 1035, the
two kingdoms were once more declared independent and remained so apart from a
short period from 1040 to 1042 when Cnut's son [Harthacnut](/wiki/Harthacnut
"Harthacnut") ascended the English throne.[25]

## Invasions of
1066[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Norse_activity_in_the_British_Isles&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Invasions of 1066")]

The [Battle of Fulford](/wiki/Battle_of_Fulford "Battle of Fulford") took
place at Fulford near [York](/wiki/York "York"), on 20 September 1066, when an
invading Norwegian force led by King [Harald Hardrada](/wiki/Harald_Hardrada
"Harald Hardrada") of Norway and [Tostig Godwinson](/wiki/Tostig_Godwinson
"Tostig Godwinson"), his English ally, fought and defeated the Northern Earls
[Edwin](/wiki/Edwin,_Earl_of_Mercia "Edwin, Earl of Mercia") and
[Morcar](/wiki/Morcar "Morcar"). When King [Harold II of
England](/wiki/Harold_II_of_England "Harold II of England") heard of this
defeat he marched his English army from the south coast of England to meet the
Norwegians at [Stamford
Bridge](/wiki/Stamford_Bridge,_East_Riding_of_Yorkshire "Stamford Bridge, East
Riding of Yorkshire").[26]

The [Battle of Stamford Bridge](/wiki/Battle_of_Stamford_Bridge "Battle of
Stamford Bridge") took place near the village of Stamford, East Riding of
Yorkshire in England on 25 September 1066. The Norwegian invasion was repelled
but before the English Army had fully recovered, the Normans—under the
leadership of Duke William II of Normandy ([William the
Conqueror](/wiki/William_the_Conqueror "William the Conqueror"))—invaded
Anglo-Saxon England. William defeated Harold II of England's army at the
[Battle of Hastings](/wiki/Battle_of_Hastings "Battle of Hastings").

##
Evidence[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Norse_activity_in_the_British_Isles&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Evidence")]

### Written
records[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Norse_activity_in_the_British_Isles&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Written records")]

Archaeologists James Graham-Campbell and Colleen E. Batey noted that there was
a lack of historical sources discussing the earliest Viking encounters with
the British Isles, which would have most probably been amongst the northern
island groups, those closest to Scandinavia.[27]

The _[Irish Annals](/wiki/Irish_Annals "Irish Annals")_ provide us with
accounts of much Norse activity during the 9th and 10th centuries.[28]

The Viking raids that affected Anglo-Saxon England were primarily documented
in the _[Anglo-Saxon Chronicle](/wiki/Anglo-Saxon_Chronicle "Anglo-Saxon
Chronicle")_ , a collection of annals initially written in the late 9th
century, most probably in the Kingdom of Wessex during the reign of [Alfred
the Great](/wiki/Alfred_the_Great "Alfred the Great"). The _Chronicle_ is
however a biased source, acting as a piece of "wartime propaganda" written on
behalf of the Anglo-Saxon forces against their Norse opponents, and in many
cases greatly exaggerates the size of the Norse fleets and armies, thereby
making any Anglo-Saxon victories against them seem more heroic.[29]

### Archaeological
evidence[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Norse_activity_in_the_British_Isles&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Archaeological evidence")]

The Norse settlers in the British Isles left remains of their [material
culture](/wiki/Material_culture "Material culture") behind, which
[archaeologists](/wiki/Archaeology "Archaeology") have been able to
[excavate](/wiki/Excavation_\(archaeology\) "Excavation \(archaeology\)") and
interpret during the 20th and 21st centuries. Such Norse evidence in Britain
consists primarily of Norse burials undertaken in Shetland, Orkney, the
Western Isles, the Isle of Man, Ireland and the north-west of England.[28]
Archaeologists James Graham-Campbell and Colleen E. Batey remarked that it was
on the Isle of Man where Norse archaeology was "remarkably rich in quality and
quantity".[3]

However, as archaeologist [Julian D. Richards](/wiki/Julian_D._Richards
"Julian D. Richards") commented, Scandinavians in Anglo-Saxon England "can be
elusive to the archaeologist" because many of their houses and graves are
indistinguishable from those of the other populations living in the
country.[2] For this reason, historian Peter Hunter Blair noted that in
Britain, the archaeological evidence for Norse invasion and settlement was
"very slight compared with the corresponding evidence for the Anglo-Saxon
invasions" of the 5th century.[28]
